title: What level of guitar playing do you need to play in a band? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ll give you the basics of what is expected of you. First, let me say this: you can jump in and play with people at any time, as long as they understand you’re not very good at playing. This means you may not know a lot of chords, may struggle with keeping up, may struggle with playing too fast. But that’s okay, you have to start somewhere. And if everyone isn’t particularly good at playing, then you’re all in the same boat and it becomes about learning to play with other musicians for all of you. And that is awesome! However, if you want to be ready to play like you actually know what you’re doing before joining a band, here is a list of things you should be working on. Now, you don’t have to be great at any or all of them, but you should be working these things out, and show improvement over time, enough for the other musicians to be okay with what you struggle with… because all musicians struggle with something or a few things. So, here is the list… When you play with other musicians, there is an expectation you know how to keep time - steady time. So you need to work with a metronome. This is the best tool to help you learn to keep a steady beat and time. You see, too many players rely upon the drummer as their time keeper. But it isn’t their job to keep the band on beat and in time. It is everyone’s job. So do not neglect this important job - learning to stay on beat and in time! The drummer will be most appreciative. Rhythm. Ninety percent of your playing is going to be rhythm guitar, not “lead” guitar solos. So, you need to know how to strum things, know multiple strum patterns, and you need to know your chords, and be able to learn new chords pretty quickly (within a couple days at most to where you can play them in context of the songs they’re in). You need to know how to take direction when you do join a band. If you are not the leader, somebody invariably will “take the lead” in directing the band, if they haven’t already done so. And if everyone is okay with the “leader”, then let it be and let them lead, as long as it is what and where you want to focus. You don’t need to be great. You just need to be able to keep up. Learn a bunch of songs and play the rhythm part along with the record. Can you keep up? If you can mostly keep time, keep up with the record, that is great! This is what you’ll be doing with the band. Learn a lot of different styles. Don’t stick with just your favourite. You cut yourself off from some great opportunities when you focus only on one thing. Trust me, variety is awesome because you’ll learn more stuff sooner than if you stick with one style/genre. Learning to solo takes time, so even if you want to be a “lead” guitar player, you will find a lot more bands in need of a good rhythm player. Learn a couple scales. The Pentatonic minor scale is important. The Major scale is also very, very important. Learn these scales in all five positions up the neck, and also learn them in every key - especially E, A, D, B Take some lessons from a good teacher if you are not already doing so; they’ll help you really get yourself ready to play with other musicians if you want to be decent before you begin playing in a band. But like I said, you can jump in at any point in your progress. And as long as the other players are at about your same level or slightly better, and don’t mind including you, you’re good to go! Also, once you’re in a group, you invariably want to play with people who are better than you, too. They don’t have to be part of the band, you can play with them separately. This will really inspire you to play beyond yourself. And, honestly? Bass players - good bass players - are even more sought after than guitar players. Everyone wants to play guitar, few want to play bass. And a good bass player is worth their weight in gold, no matter if it is just a garage band or a major touring act. (If you are seeking lessons, I teach via Skype. Contact me via private message if you are interested. My rates are reasonable.)

It so depends on the band and your role in it. Lets look at a minimum and a midlevel case while understand the upper limit is way up there. For the minimum, let’s say you are the main singer in a singer/songwriter kind of outfit playing cafe and bar gigs. In that role, you might need an acoustic and maybe a basic electric. You would need to be able to play all chord changes in all the songs, while singing. You might only need a basic clean tone, in tune and not too loud. You provide the harmonic framework, just as you would in your own bedroom rehersals. The other players should support you with complimentary parts. So, in this case, not a particularly high level. In the midline example, we will say you are the only guitar player in a cover band, doing only background vocals. Now you have a couple of guitars on an AB switch and a pedal board into a decent amp. You mostly play chords, but in more varied voicings, in more places on the neck. When there are guitar solos, you play them, at least suggesting the original. You are turning knobs, switching pedals and changing instruments to sound like the originals. You will not only understand the tunes and your options for chords, scales and tones, you will need to communicate with the bass player and maybe a keyboard player, in a musically technical way. You may need to transpose songs into new keys to allow the singer to hit the right pitches. In this case, you need to be a mid pack guitarist with a broad catalog of chords, be a fair soloist, know basic music theory and be able to manage your tone while performing.

A VERY good question actually, though rather loaded. There is some good news and some bad news here and I’ll start with the bad news: It’s a LOT more difficult than it used to be. This is mostly due to a perfect storm of a. rock/metal/punk etc. going back to being more underground b. hiphop/EDM/bubblegum pop etc. being the mainstream and having been for about 30 years c. just about everything on the guitar having already been done before and d. way more gear being way more readily available (though good, solid pro-gear and nice guitars will cost a month’s rent and your soul) thus a HUGE glut of guitarists and e. thanks to the internet/youtube era it’s a lot more competitive than it was back when Zappa and Hendrix had their time. It’s all actually less a blame thing and more of an inevitability due to time and wear and tear of the artform. That’s just part of it though, it’s a lot more difficult because there are almost no more garage bands anymore. It just sucks for contemporary musicians to get their feet off the ground now and it’s a LOT more difficult to manage the expenses of having good gear, practice space where you can play without having the cops called on you (if you’re unfortunate enough you might have to pay to rent a studio room,) actually joining or starting a band in the first place with others that have similar levels of dedication/taste/vision/goals (especially a bass player of ANY sort PERIOD) and scheduling rehearsals and gigs… and even if you are fortunate enough to come across that and DO get paying gigs expect to make less than peanuts let alone minimum wage. True, if you’re dedicated and persistent enough you can also be fortunate enough to sign on to a major label but oh MAN is that ever a temple of traps now that I can go on about ALL NIGHT. It’s so bad you can “make it” and STILL end up owing the label money! Self-producing is the way to go in these modern times IF you can do it. Also a lot of the difficulty has to do with the cutthroat competitiveness of it now. As I mentioned, back when Zappa and Hendrix were huge almost nobody had their skills (save classical and jazz purists but that’s a completely different ballpark than what I’m talking.) Back then in the good ol’ days of guitar, it was still fresh and new; you didn’t have to be FANTASTIC in order to make a good living off of it. Now in this youtube era all you have to do is choose a random video of someone playing guitar and it’s quite likely they would’ve been good enough to be a big star back in the 60s - 90s. It’s just consequence… to the point where it’s just not as impressive as it used to be sadly in this era where you can go on the net and fairly easily find a video of some 7 year old girl in some hut in Indonesia (for example) playing Petrucci stuff with no sweat like she wrote it. It can be flat-out discouraging for a lot of people… especially in this “there’s a school for literally everything” American Idol “music is a competition because everything is competition” era… at least back in the 70s and 80s there was Punk Rock. I’m sorry to be so somber about this all… I just feel really sorry for guitarists in this day and age; they’ve got it so rough. Having great skills at the guitar in these times is like being a multi-millionaire in a dead, over-inflated currency that can’t be exchanged. Now for the GOOD news: It’s STILL all completely subjective. Every player has a different experience so there’s no “one size fits all” answer. If you are doing this for fun and joy ALONE you will have a far easier time with all of this, so long as you can communicate it well to others and are crystal clear about it… it’s pretty Zen actually. I also say no matter what you do, where you are with your playing… yes work on your chops/getting better but I don’t recommend obsessing over them (especially watching/comparing yourself to viral youtube guitarists) otherwise you will NEVER feel “good enough” to even TRY auditioning/starting a band. I made that fatal burnout-inducing mistake back when I used to play/was serious about playing and MAN do I ever regret it. I’d rather be a decent rhythm player with the courage to even TRY auditioning/starting a band/writing songs than be able to play Allan Holdsworth, Joe Pass, Paco De Lucia, Michael Romero etc. in my sleep but too afraid of what “others” (usually simply other musicians) think to actually do something with it. TL;DR What level of guitar playing do you need to play in a band? If you ask me, there is no definitive answer as there are more variables than I can count. Just remember, don’t become so critical of yourself that you won’t try and find YOUR answer to this. Best wishes!

ANGUS YOUNG WITH GIBSON SG. I think if you can play basic chords on guitar you can play in a band, two examples that indicate this come from my reading of books about ACDC and JOHNNY CASH. JOHNNY CASH “I was there when it happened" a title from a Johnny Cash song, was used as the title of his bassist and one time manager, Marshall Grant’s book on his time with Cash, who stated when they first got together as friends in Memphis on the weekends, Johnny Cash, Luther Perkins and Marshall Grant all played acoustic guitars together when singing. Johnny said one day, or evening, something like, “If we wanna be famous like Elvis and make a record we better learn to play other instruments!” [meaning Bass and Lead Guitar]. Marshall Grant said he had never played a bass before but borrowed one from a friend, he didn't know how to tune it so got someone else to teach him, when he did learn to play it he got well known for his ‘slap-pick' style which added percussion to their first recordings. They didn't have a drummer at the start and W.S. Holland was brought in later, as was D.J. Fontana who joined Elvis and the Blue Moon Boys (Scotty Moore and Bill Black).  The Blue Moon Boys, Bill Black (Bass), Elvis Presley (acoustic guitar) and Scotty Moore (lead guitar.) Luther Perkins bought a second hand electric guitar which had a stuck ‘volume' knob, which was stuck in the high volume position. To counter this and not drown out the other guys, Johnny suggested he weave a dollar bill between the strings, this also provided a percussive sound and his style of dulling the strings (palm-muting) when picking gave the band the ‘Johnny Cash sound'. Johnny Cash also strummed pretty hard and had a habit of simply placing his fingers across the strings without pushing them down on the fretboard and strumming, this was another percussive style that can be heard on many of his early Sun Records recordings. So what I am saying here is these guys used or accidently invented their own playing styles using simple chords but gave them their distinctive ‘boom-chicka-boom' sound which was used wonderfully in train songs to copy the sounds of the clickety-clack of train wheels across railway tracks.  Johnny Cash and the Tennessee Two, Luther Perkins (lead guitar) and Marshall Grant (bass) [not shown]. ACDC The ACDC sound is instantly recognised by Rock fans the world over, and considering they mostly played basic chords (or power chords) they created a hard rock sound. All through their years of recording and playing live concerts, the brothers, Angus Young on his Gibson SG and older brother, the late Malcolm Young on his Gretsch guitar created great riffs many of them starting with Malcolm on rhythm guitar. Their style included plenty of palm-muting, hitting certain strings of a chord, hammer-ons, pull-offs, basic amp settings on full volume, a little sustain and other settings at about mid range on Marshall Amps. So you can play in any band really simply by playing basic chords, its all really a matter of technique, creating your own style of playing. Kurt Cobain played some pretty insane chords as a left-handed guitar player, as did Jimi Hendrix who could strum and pick a left-handed or right-handed guitar upside down. Early BeachBoys guitarist, Glen Campbell (known for his country music) played lead guitar on most of their early hits. What was remarkable about that? He was naturally left-handed but played right-handed guitars, right-handed.  Glen Campbell guitar solos 1960-2000.

Many famous bands have started with relative unexperienced gitarist. As long as they share the same vision with their band companions, they might be able to contribute enough in the band to feel musically comfortably. Playing in a band should be fun! I guess that your question in som way reflects a notion that there is a certain level you must reach before you start advertising for yourself as a guitarist. What I recommend is this: Learn the Basic chords, and learn som strumming and picking techniques. Also try to learn som easy solos, and songs you like to play. Then its time to search for bandmates. Important: playing together is something different than playing alone. Be open about your skilles and fars. When your playing with others, remember that we are bor with two ears and one mouth, or in this case - a guitar. Be polite, dont imagine youre a guitar hero, and listen to the other people in the band. Do not play much louder than the other. Hopefully you and youre bandmates get along and are having fun. Paul Brobakken, Norway

You need to be able to hold the guitar so that the strings are pointing outwards.  Everything else is strictly optional. The Sex Pistols, one of Britain’s most talked about bands, revealed only rudimentary musical ability.* If you can play the chords that are in the songs you are doing, and play them like you mean it (even if they sound terrible), then you’re going to connect with some audience at some point. Find your audience, and keep playing for them, and you will be successful. The studio can always hire in session musicians when you come to record an album. Practically speaking, be as good as you can be, but don’t wait. Joining a band will do far more for your playing than anything else can.  *They were actually better than they pretended to be. If you listen to their version of Johnny B Goode, they reveal chops that they kept concealed on their own songs. Go on, listen to it—it is the funniest version you will ever hear.

At a minimum, you need to be able to competently play rhythm guitar along to cover songs in the genre or genres that interest you. You should be able to play in time with the song, at full tempo. Depending on genres, amount of time to practice, determination, and raw talent, this could be anywhere from 1–3 years. At that point, you can start seeking out similarly experienced fellow musicians to form a first band. You will not, after posting a video of muddying your way through “Atlas Rise!” get a call from James Hetfield asking you to fill in for Kirk at the gig tonight because Kirk pricked his pinky and can’t play. Kirk hasn’t used his pinky since the Black Album anyway. Have realistic starting and growth goals. Try to play with people who are slightly better than you, when you can. But the important thing is to practice, even a little, EVERY SINGLE DAY, and play with other people as often as you can, once you’re ready to start.

It depends on the band and the music you’re playing. If you’re playing simple music (and note that a lot of rock is simple), and you’re playing with other people who are not advanced musicians (but who still please an audience that likes loud, simple music), then you may do alright even if you’re not all that skilled. I’ve seen some bands that had players simply banging basic chords on their guitars — and I mean banging — through Marshall stacks. Very simple, but rhythmic, with a screaming singer, and the audience liked it. I remember a guy who hoarsely said, “My band plays three chords real loud!” So it depends on what the band wants to do. Try to connect with other players who like and want to play the kind of music you want to play. You might join a band even if you’ve only been playing about a year. My first garage band was a lot of fun, and we got a few gigs. I enjoy remembering those experiences.

A little note here, I’m old school, played pro and semi-pro for 40–45 years playing electric and upright bass and singing. Outside of soloing, the best thing a guitar player can do when playing rhythm is, hold it,…..not much, and do it in time. A lot depends on the size of the band. In a trio he/she has to do more work/playing, but I just cant tell you how many guitarists try to play on every beat and usually way to loud. Typically a band has 4 or more people playing instruments and if every one is playing as much as they can, then it just comes out as a wall of noise. Oh your friends may like it but really it ain’t good. All that extra stuff may sound good in the bedroom but on stage it just takes away from the groove that a good bass and drums are trying to create. So really the answer to your question is to play like an expensive dinner, a small amount with great taste.

You don’t need much. Life is short. Go do it. There is nothing like being forced to play for a couple of hours to develop your skills. At least develop your muscles. Play with a band who cater to an audience that is more forgiving. Play at old people home, play at Church, play at the hospital at the cancer ward. I’ve done it and it is very affirmative. Also, you learn valuable lessons that you don’t want to learn gigging for a paying audience. These lessons include the basics of gigging, equipment failure, spare guitar, sound failure, load in, load out, *playing to make the audience happy* and not playing what you want to play, labeling your equipments not losing cables, dropping and tripping over your guitar. Playing for 50 minutes without a break. What to do on stage when you are not playing in the song. What to do if one member is missing. Covering others during their weak part. Having a good time so the audience will have a good time. You are going to learn a lot - especially if you have not gigged before. Just because the audience is not paying, you still need to be professional and treat them with respect. That will carry on with you in your whole career.

The Word “band” covers a multitude of ….sins. To play in a punk rock band, I suspect that having a vague idea of which way to hold an electric guitar whilst you hit it, is sufficient. To play in a big band/orchestral environment, then you would need to be able to sight read and play exotic chords and rhythms in every key. I am very competent in my styles of acoustic guitar, but I’d be useless playing Freddie Green style rhythm in a big band … or in a pub rock band (where I’d probably really hope to be sacked asap).

The trick is to know and be honest about how good you really are. Then, you will be able to hook up with other people at the same level and expectations as yourself. When I was in high school, some one offered to sell me a guitar and I turned them down. Then they told me it was only $16 and I said what the heck. That's how I started playing guitar. I started My first band a couple weeks later and self described it as pro nuke junk rock - the final battle. To join, you could not know how to play your instrument and the songs were improvised on the spot. We had the police called on us a couple times. A year later I had disbanded because I got too good just fiddling around and it didn't sound the same anymore. I discovered I could sing and have been focusing on that. Today, if you want to be in a band with me, you better be damn good or you won't make the cut. Time changes and we all start somewhere. And hopefully we grow. So personnel changes Happen because of that. Its ok. Good luck!

An old joke: if you know three chords you can play in a rock band to an audience of 3,000. If you know 3,000 chords you can play in a jazz band to an audience of 3. Seriously, it depends on the band and whether the guitar needs to be a virtuoso instrument, or not. It’s a valid choice. Does anyone care how good a guitarist Bob Dylan is? BUT - you have to play in time, and in tune. However simple the piece. And if you know how to groove a bit too (Nile Rogers comes to mind…) then we’re talking.

There are players of various levels as well as bands. You can play in a band of beginners only knowing 3 chords. If you want to gain proficiency take some lessons from a qualified teacher either face to face or through Skype. Go to as many jams as you can playing with different people and practicing different styles. Work on your timing playing with backing tracks and practice practice practice. You will know when you are ready as that varies stronhly per individual. When you can play what you hear without thinking you are close. Good luck and have fun. By the way, these days I own a guitar boutique, am a session musician and go under the name “Blues Dog”. I have been there ;-)

You need to have acquired the skill, confidence, determination, and patience to perform in a band. These traits will evolve as you gain performance experience. If you already have these elements at your fingertips (and you have learned some tunes in the style of your choice), you can look around for some musician friends to start a band or a band that will welcome a newcomer to the fold. Talk to musicians that you know and see if you can set up a few jam sessions. As you shop around for the right fit you will gain combo experience and confidence along the way. As long as you know your way around the guitar and you have a good chord inventory with soloing skills, you are ready to step into the arena. Good luck!

The honest answer is your skill level just needs to be relatively close to the others in the band. You obviously wouldn’t want to join an established band if you are just starting out, and a competent musician probably wouldn’t want to join a band that was all beginners. Now go find some people to play with and have the time of your life!!!

Well it must be actually a merit level or above because the band members actually are finding some players that can play some riffs or solos and can actually make their band famous or to people's eye. If you are just started playing guitar some weeks ago, you should forget and get some experience and cross the level of extraordinary. Just try to be virtuous and you may be one day and that day will come when you will practice and stop making excuses.

wow! i was fifteen and in a band and we were very popular! two of the only electric guitar players in a town of 50,000 in 1962! we could cover (badly) about 30 of the top forty instrumentals (we had no singer) and had an electric accordian (gasp!), drums and a tenor sax. we played wipeout, the lonely bull, pipeline walk don't run hot pastrami etc. today no one would hire us or even listen to us. pick your genre. learn to cover at least 30 songs and how to avoid taking requests. take a few "no pay" gigs where your songs might be appreciated. learn new songs every week. by yourself and together. listen to the music you want to become good at. keep looking for gigs where you might be appreciated. look for gigs that paid even a few bucks. practice at home on your ax, practice with the group or with one or two members of the group. you can make miracles happen; never stop improving. you can't just walk into a group. you gotta work with a few other beginners and become good together. if you try hard, you WILL succeed! stay well

I’ll give the short and practical answer, but probably not what you are looking for. Answer: The same “level” of musicianship as the other players in the band or slightly above. In other words, don’t think too hard about it. Just do it. Find some people who want to play and just start playing.

At least the same level as the rest of the band plays. If you’re joining a band made up of highschoolers who just learned everything from YouTube in two months, then you only need to know as much guitar as a high schooler who learned everythiung from YouTube in two months, or better. Likewise, if you want to join a super good jazz band, you have to play at their level, with the requisite knowledge in music theory, and an equally skillful technique.

You only need to know 3 chords to start jamming with a rythmn section…it's all about getting in and staying in "the pocket"….Or start with 3 songs on acoustic and do an open mic…practice to a metronome and learn to sing while playing, while you're just beginning…this will help you cover songs with solid tempo… If you're trying to play lead…jam with a rythmn section a ton and when there are other humans playing, keep your volume down except when you're really "feeling" it…and build an instinct for when a solo might start and stop appropriately. Your jam mates will tell you if you are "meshing" well or not…

When you want to play three chord songs three chords will do. More important are things like discipline, choosing a 'repertoire', wllingness to listen to each other, forgive each others mistakes, but be critical at the same time. When you start performing, the audience will respond, how do you deal with that response. How do you deal with the attention (some members will get more attention, probably not proportional to the contribution to the band). How do you behave on stage, do you all pose "look at me!" at the same time? Are all of you shoegazers/wallflowers? When some girls start complaining to one of the members about some of the songs, will you remove those songs? Money, rehearsal room, transport, practical things.. The casual image of bands often denies they have these things sorted out.

You don't have to be that good at all. Of course, you'll likely be among people of a similar level, and there is nothing wrong with that. It's more important to follow the beat of the drummer, have solid fun, and get along with your bamdmates. All the talent in the world doesn't guarantee a good output. I've seen people who can only strum and play 3 chords bring down the house. I've seen technical meastros cause a massive walk-out.

You just need to have a good sense of rhythm and be able play and switch between basic chords to start, and keep in time with the rest of the band. I started in 1984 and was in a college band in 1985, playing power chords, mainly. I worked at good rhythm and people thought I could play well, but I was such a basic player…..with good rhythm.

The same level as those you hope to play with. Many great songs can be played by those with less than a year of practice. Many subpar musicians have achieved great success. Start at the garage and work your way up.

Bands come at all levels - and since you will part of the band you’ll also be part of the band’s level. My band was also my friends - so the personalities count as well. A band seems to be most ‘stable’ when the members are somewhat equal in musical skills. Don’t say to yourself: ‘I don’t want to join a band, that accepts a guy like me’ - just go for it and give it your best - without shyness. Best wishes.

Time isn’t relative - skill is. All you need is to be able to make smooth chord changes and keep a rhythm. The only difference between being a good band member and a bad one is how well you can play the songs your band expects you to know. Just learn lots of 4 chord song and most singers will we really happy with your work. if you do need a time line - 6 months of solid practice. YouTube is your best friend.

It all depends on what type of band you are playing in and also the skill level of the band you want to enter into. You will not do good as a beginner with a band that has seasoned road playing and many years of practice. If you are a beginner, you should find others that are also learning at the same time so you can become a better band together.

It depends on the genre. When I was 16, my friend and I had been playing instruments for about 4 weeks when we started a punk band haha. A couple of months later we played shows in the punk scene haha. It takes significantly more time when you want to play jazz. :)

Depends what you’re planning on playing and who you’re playing with. If it’s something with friends they’ll be a lot more forgiving and The Ramones are one of the most famous bands ever and they hardly knew the names of chords. Obviously if you’re playing jazz with professionals then that’s a whole other story
None… All you need is a power chord, an amp and some willing friends. That’s the great thing about guitar!
Exactly as much as is needed for that band in particular- and you don’t want too much more or too much less.
You can play straight chords through everything and as long as you're solid it can work. You don't have to play lead.
